On Wednesday evening, an international consortium of research collaborations revealed evidence for the existence of a low-pitch hum of gravitational waves reverberating across the universe. This hum is likely the collective echo of pairs of supermassive black holes merging in the early universe. The signal was discovered by studying the behavior of rapidly spinning stars called pulsars, using a method that in 1993 earned two scientists the Nobel Prize in Physics. This hum is so loud that it could be coming from hundreds of thousands, or possibly a million, overlapping signals from the cosmic merger history of supermassive black hole binaries. The findings were consistent with Albert Einstein’s theory of general relativity, and could help researchers understand how the universe achieved its current structure and perhaps reveal exotic types of matter that may have existed shortly after the Big Bang. This is just the beginning of a whole new way to observe the universe.

  1. The Very Large Array on the Plains of San Agustin, N.M. was one of three radio telescopes that worked with a global consortium to detect the timing of pulsars.
  2. The international consortium of research collaborations revealed compelling evidence for the existence of a low-pitch hum of gravitational waves reverberating across the universe.
  3. The hum is suspected to be the collective echo of pairs of supermassive black holes, some as massive as a billion suns, sitting at the hearts of ancient galaxies up to 10 billion light-years away.
